text: S. R. P. Silva · R. R. Maciel · M. C. G. Severino
Cenozoic tectonics of Amazon Mouth Basin
Received: 20 August 1996 / Revision received: 11 June 1998

Abstract The Cenozoic shelf margin of the Amazon
Mouth Basin is characterized by a thick prograding prism
of siliciclastic sediments. This prism, composed mainly of
Upper Miocene and younger sediments, overlies a Lower
Tertiary
carbonate
shelf.
Two
tectonic—sedimentary
models for the area were developed with the aid of new
deep-reﬂection seismic data. Gravitational tectonics dom-
inate the regional geological framework. Tensional stres-
ses are created near the shelf margin, and compressional
features dominate at the base of the slope. The morpho-
logy of this compressional zone is closely associated with
the St. Paul Fracture Zone and the boundary between
continental and oceanic crusts.
Introduction

The Amazon Mouth Basin, located on the northwest part
of the Brazilian equatorial continental margin, covers an
area of about 360,000 km2 (Fig. 1). This area includes the
continental shelf, slope, and deep basin down to the
3000-m isobath. The base of the stratigraphic sequence is
composed
of
rift
sediments
of
Aptian—Albian
age
(120 Ma) that are related to the South Atlantic opening
(Castro et al. 1978; Resende and Ferradaes 1971). There
are three main drift sequences that overlie the rift
sediments: an earlier
transgressive marine sequence
(100—65 Ma), a carbonate platform (65—10 Ma), and
a younger, thick prograding siliciclastic marine sequence
(10—0 Ma) related to
Amazon River sedimentation.
The central part of the Cenozoic shelf margin, known as
‘‘Cone do Amazonas’’, is aﬀected by intense gravity
tectonics (Fig. 1).
A structural analysis of the Amazon mouth basin was
ﬁrst presented by Resende and Ferradaes (1971). In their

Methodology

For this work we used multichannel seismic reﬂection
proﬁles and gravity and well data. The seismic reﬂection
data were collected along lines 15,000 km long and spaced
10—40 km apart. In the Cone do Amazonas region, this
data set includes 4500 km of new deep-penetration
seismic data collected at 12 and 18 s recorded time. The
previous seismic data were reprocessed using wavelet de-
convolution, multiple attenuation, and after-stack fre-
quency ﬁlters. Gravity data, collected on a 10]10-km
grid, were used to prepare Bouguer and Bouguer-ﬁltered
maps and 2D gravity models (Fig. 2); some of these data
are available in the work presented by Silva and Rodarte
(1989) and Braga (1991). The integration of these data
with the seismic observations allowed us to deﬁne the
tectonic framework and the boundary between continen-
tal and oceanic crusts.
The interpretation of seismic sections was integrated
with data from 26 wells and led to the identiﬁcation of six
megasequences: one rift (Early Cretaceous) and ﬁve drift
(Late Cretaceous and Cenozoic). The drift megasequences
comprise the following time intervals: Late Cretaceous
(100—65 Ma), Paleocene—Eocene (65—40 Ma), Oligocene
(40—25 Ma), Early to Middle Miocene (25—10 Ma), and
Late Miocene to Recent (10—0 Ma) (Fig. 3). The limits of
these megasequences were mapped and converted to

Results

In seismic reﬂection proﬁles, the Paleocene—Middle Miocene
megasequence appears as continuous, parallel, high-ampli-
tude seismic facies (Fig. 3). This pattern indicates a relative-
ly stable platform. Well-hole data also indicate a carbonate
platform environment for most of this megasequence. Some
platform subenvironments, such as banks of red algae, large
foraminifera, and ooliths, are described in this area (Wolﬀ
and Carozzi 1984). The continental shelf at the mouth of
the Amazon River is 300 km wide. The megasequences
interval thicknesses are 1000 m for Paleocene—Eocene,
200 m for Oligocene, and 1500 m for Early to Middle
Miocene. On the Amapa coast (Fig. 5), shelf sediments are
thinner (1200 m) and the width is narrower (120 km) for the

Paleocene—Middle Miocene interval. In the central part of
the basin, from the Paleocene to the Middle Miocene, the
shelf edge deviates from the NW—SE trend seen today.
The shelf edge shows a reentrant conﬁguration that marks
the southwestern limit of the so-called Cone do Amazonas
(Fig. 1). Canyons cutting the platform near the shelf edge
are most common in this area (Fig. 5). In the Cone do
Amazonas region, the Paleocene—Middle Miocene mega-
sequences have two depocenters. The southeastern one is
about 5500 m thick and the northwestern one is about
5000 m thick (Fig. 5). Near the shelf edge these sediments
are deformed by listric faults and by thrust faults farther
seaward (Fig. 3). In contrast, out of the Cone do Ama-
zonas region, the deep basin sediments are thinner
(1000 m, Fig. 5) and less aﬀected by gravity tectonics.
The younger Late Miocene—Recent megasequence
appears in seismic proﬁles with a low-amplitude discon-
tinuous seismic facies (Fig. 3). This megasequence has a
progradational feature. A ﬂuvio deltaic—continental slope
system was determined from sedimentary and petro-
graphic studies of well samples (Castro et al. 1978). Well-
log analysis indicated overpressured sediments in this
megasequence (Franke 1975). During this period of time,
the continental shelf edge migrated to form the present-
day regional NW—SE trend (Fig. 1). In response to the
great increase in the sediment supply rate and associated
gravity tectonics, the shelf edge shows a slightly convex
eastward shape. This progradational prism is 9000 m

thick at the northwestern part of the Cone do Amazonas
region (Figs. 4 and 6). Elsewhere in the basin, it is only

There are several regularly spaced and relatively con-
tinuous listric faults between the shelf edge and the Late
Miocene—Recent depocenter. These faults commonly
trend along the same fault surfaces as the Paleocene—
Middle Miocene early gravity faults (Figs. 3 and 7). In the
depocenter there is another set of listric faults, aﬀecting
only the Late Miocene—Recent megasequence (Figs. 4 and
7). In this set, the faults are laterally shorter and farther
apart. On the deeper part of the Cone do Amazonas
region, there are two sets of thrust faults associated with
gravity tectonics (Figs. 4 and 7): a northwestern one and
a southeastern one (near the shelf edge). Their external
limits are the transition zone for continental and oceanic
crust. The St. Paul Fracture Zone is closely related to
oﬀsets of both features (Fig. 7). The intense sedimentation
during the Late Miocene—Recent (related with the Ama-
zon River) and the associated gravity tectonics led to the
present convex surface of the ocean bottom (Fig. 8).
Discussion

In
the
Amazon
Mouth
Basin,
deposition
of
the
Paleocene—Middle Miocene megasequences is closely re-

lated to the previous tectonic evolution of the rift. For the
Amapa coast, the existence of deep grabens indicates
major crustal stretching during the rift phase, which pro-
moted a high subsequent thermal subsidence (Fig. 1). In
front of the present Amazon mouth, the development of
a large stable shelf was a consequence of a thinner and less
stretched crust. Great canyons were formed near the shelf
edge during major times of lowstand sea level in the
Eocene, Oligocene, and Miocene (Figs. 5 and 6) (Silva and
Rodarte, 1989). Clastic sediments bypassed the shelf edge
through these canyons and reached the continental slope.
An increase of sedimentary weight (related to sedimenta-
tion rate) in unstable areas, such as along the continental
slope, creates ideal conditions for the development of
gravity tectonics. The importance of these tectonics on the
origin of growth faulting in deltaic areas, such as the US
Gulf Coast Province and the Niger and Mississippi deltas,
has been discussed in the literature (Crans et al. 1980;
Winker 1982; Galloway 1986).
In the Amazon Mouth Basin, Castro et al. (1978) identi-
ﬁed growth faults and interpreted compressional features
as diapiric structures. The acquisition of new seismic re-
ﬂection data and the use of new processing routines,
however, allowed us to identify the former diapirs as
compressional structures (folds and thrust faults) and to
deﬁne new tectonic models for this area based on gravity
gliding and spreading (Galloway 1986). In the ﬁrst
model, gravity gliding creates extensional ﬁelds on the

continental slope (Fig. 9A1). As a result, growth faults and
rollover structures were formed. The faults tend to termin-
ate over mechanical discontinuities near the top of the rift
and early Paleocene sequences (Fig. 3). Along these dis-
continuities, the potential energy of sliding is enough to
overcome the internal strength of the sediments, allowing
the sedimentary blocks to be carried toward deeper
waters. In deep water, the topography of the St. Paul
Fracture Zone and the transition zone between the conti-
nental and oceanic crust resists this down-slope transla-
tion. Thus, friction increases on the sliding surfaces near
the ridge, and compressional stresses are created. In re-
sponse to these processes, high subsidence rates and thick
sedimentary deposits are created at the base of continental
slope. Another increase in the sediment thickness results
in the deep-water compressive areas due to the stacking of
overthrusted blocks (Fig. 9A2).
The early Tertiary carbonate deposition on the conti-
nental shelf was interrupted by the change in the direction
of ﬂow of the Amazon River, from west to east into the
Atlantic Ocean, due to the Andean Orogeny (Hoorn
1993). Consequently, since middle Miocene time, a ﬂuvio
deltaic—continental slope system has been developing in
the Amazon Mouth Basin.
The high capacity of sediment transport by the Amazon
River caused an increase in the sedimentation rates.
During the last second-order lowstand of sea level (Late

Miocene to Recent), this sedimentation prograded to near
the shelf edge and stayed there longer than during the
Paleocene—Middle Miocene time. In the Cone do Ama-
zonas region, the situation of the relative lowstand of sea
level associated with the increase of sediment inﬂux al-
lowed the accumulation of large volumes of sediment on
the continental slope. The earlier gravity tectonics were
intensiﬁed mainly because of two factors: increased sedi-
mentary load in an unstable area, and creation of new
gliding surfaces. These surfaces tend to follow abnormally
high pressure zones that usually occur in areas of high
sedimentation rates and rapid subsidence (Dailly 1976).
The distribution pattern of a thick sedimentary load,
mainly on the western side of the Cone do Amazonas
region, promoted high subsidence rates. The gravitational
tectonic intensity led to the northward displacement of the
western part of the Paleocene—Middle Miocene structural
thickening (Figs. 4 and 5). Thus, the northwestern Paleo-
cene—Middle Miocene structural thickening is closely
related with the post-Miocene compressional region. The
southeastern sedimentary thickening is related to the ex-
tensional region that was active during its deposition
(Fig. 5).

Conclusions
Major conclusions are:

1. The Amazon Cenozoic shelf conﬁguration is closely
related to the previous tectonic evolution of the
rift.
2. The Amazon Mouth Basin is a good example of
gravity tectonics in a complex prograding continental
margin.
3. Near the shelf edge, growth faults and rollover struc-
tures were formed by gravity gliding. Along the
margins of the deep basin, the compressional struc-
tures were formed by both gravity gliding and spread-
ing.
4. The morphology of the compressional zone is closely
associated with topographic irregularities (ridge) of the
St. Paul Fracture Zone and the boundary between
continental and oceanic crusts.
5. The gravity tectonics active since Paleocene were inten-
siﬁed after the Middle Miocene due to the high sedi-
mentation rates of the Amazon River.
